abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, though
            institutional development impacts were only modest. Among
            the lessons learned, the project experience suggests
            cofinancing as an instrument to prod sector policies, target
            public investment, and concentrate efforts to alleviate
            poverty, resulting in addition, in a quick disbursement of
            loan operations. A flexible financing for recurrent costs
            might motivate States in pursuing Bank procurement, and
            expenditure procedures. Another lesson suggests that program
            implementation should include a participative process,
            articulated within medium term regional, or sectoral
            programs, while decentralization should not only include
            municipalities, but be part of the demand-driven,
            participatory planning approach. Nevertheless, and despite
            success, emphasis of future projects should be placed on
            technical assistance, training, and institutional building
            at the States, and regional levels, based on existing local
            institutions (government agencies, municipalities,
            farmer's organizations, nongovernmental organizations,
            etc.). Their capacity building should be a fundamental
            ingredient for success. Moreover, adaptive research,
            technology transfer, and support services should have a
            strategic, relevant role on all rural development projects
            targeting small farmers, so as to provide the required
            public goods for driving the process, and compensate the
            limited access to improved technologies, and information.
